We can move the guest selection to come before the other actors
content.html:
This would make the blue skin unusable if a different skin is set on the yaml file, which is very limiting. How about keeping all skins on the same array, but removing the guest skin after its been set, something like:

skins.delete(guest_skin)

We can move the guest selection to come before the other actors

  File "/media/louise/TERA/code/servicesim_ws/install_isolated/lib/servicesim_example_python_solution/get_bbox_distance.py", line 22, in <module>
    import imutils

@mikaelarguedas @wjwwood
content.html:
I'm getting an error here:

  File "/media/louise/TERA/code/servicesim_ws/install_isolated/lib/servicesim_example_python_solution/get_bbox_distance.py", line 22, in <module>
    import imutils
ImportError: No module named imutils

I know I could just install it with pip, but I'm looking for a way to do it automatically through rosdep, does anyone know if it's possible? Otherwise we'll need to update the install instructions

@mikaelarguedas @wjwwood

content.raw:
If it was in the rosdep database you could install it using pip (rosdep can install packages from various package managers, both apt and pip are supported on Linux). But to release a package as a deb, all its dependencies need to be available via APT so we encourage people to not use pip dependencies.


As this module is almost unused in this package (at least in this PR), I would recommend getting rid of the dependency completely.
From what I can see there is only one function used from this module: `imutils.is_cv2()`. This is [just checking](https://github.com/jrosebr1/imutils/blob/9951937054188a4a2866ba70d296eff89179b82f/imutils/convenience.py#L154) if we are using OpenCV2 or OpenCV3.
As this package is targeting kinetic, we [already know](https://github.com/ros-perception/vision_opencv/blob/kinetic/cv_bridge/package.xml#L29) that we are using OpenCV3. If the goal is to be able  to support all ROS distros (including indigo that uses openCV2), we can use the fact that OpenCV is already imported line 17, and just check the value of `cv2.__version__` would give the answer (or `cv2.__version__[0]` if we just want to know the major). So importing a different module from pip just to do so seems a bit overkill.
content.html:
If it was in the rosdep database you could install it using pip (rosdep can install packages from various package managers, both apt and pip are supported on Linux). But to release a package as a deb, all its dependencies need to be available via APT so we encourage people to not use pip dependencies.

As this module is almost unused in this package (at least in this PR), I would recommend getting rid of the dependency completely. From what I can see there is only one function used from this module: imutils.is_cv2(). This is just checking if we are using OpenCV2 or OpenCV3. As this package is targeting kinetic, we already know that we are using OpenCV3. If the goal is to be able to support all ROS distros (including indigo that uses openCV2), we can use the fact that OpenCV is already imported line 17, and just check the value of cv2.__version__ would give the answer (or cv2.__version__[0] if we just want to know the major). So importing a different module from pip just to do so seems a bit overkill.

content.raw: The messages don't depend on `std_msgs` as they use ROS message primitives directly (`float64` and not `std_msgs/Float64`). I think std_msgs dependency can be removed completely from this package (CMake, python and package.xml)

content.raw: So do you mean that int32, Float64 messages used in Contour.msg are not derived from std_msgs? and taken from the ROS message primitives?
content.html: So do you mean that int32, Float64 messages used in Contour.msg are not derived from std_msgs? and taken from the ROS message primitives?

content.raw: What I mean is that Contour.msg is using only ROS [builtin message types](http://wiki.ros.org/msg#Fields) and doesn't depend on any other message package. It doesn't use `Float64` from `std_msgs` otherwise the line in the msg file would be `std_msgs/Float64 distance`
content.html: What I mean is that Contour.msg is using only ROS builtin message types and doesn't depend on any other message package. It doesn't use Float64 from std_msgs otherwise the line in the msg file would be std_msgs/Float64 distance

content.raw: @mikaelarguedas I installed PEP8 checker for atom after seeing the changes that you suggested regarding PEP8 style coding, it shows an error that some lines like this are long and can be shifted to two lines. should I make those changes too?
content.html: @mikaelarguedas I installed PEP8 checker for atom after seeing the changes that you suggested regarding PEP8 style coding, it shows an error that some lines like this are long and can be shifted to two lines. should I make those changes too?

content.raw:
Line length is more subjective as most people agree that now the 80 character limits due to antique terminals doesnt apply anymore. I use 100 characters for the code I write as it is the style for ROS2. In ROS1 in general people stick with 120 (http://wiki.ros.org/CppStyleGuide#Line_length).  I don't know what convention Gazebo follows in general.
So I'd say if anything is longer than 120 let's split it, otherwise I don't this it's worth spending time splitting them
content.html: Line length is more subjective as most people agree that now the 80 character limits due to antique terminals doesnt apply anymore. I use 100 characters for the code I write as it is the style for ROS2. In ROS1 in general people stick with 120 (http://wiki.ros.org/CppStyleGuide#Line_length). I don't know what convention Gazebo follows in general. So I'd say if anything is longer than 120 let's split it, otherwise I don't this it's worth spending time splitting them

content.raw: On Gazebo / Ign we use 80, but on ServiceSim we're not adhering to any specific style as long as things look reasonably clean. I agree that below 120 should be good enough.
content.html: On Gazebo / Ign we use 80, but on ServiceSim we're not adhering to any specific style as long as things look reasonably clean. I agree that below 120 should be good enough.

content.raw:
What is the reason for changing `rospy.Time.now()` to `rospy.get_time()` here?
(I should double check but) I think that this will give you system time and not ROS time so this will behave differently based on the real time factor. So I suggest going back to using now() or use `rospy.get_rostime()`
content.html: What is the reason for changing rospy.Time.now() to rospy.get_time() here? (I should double check but) I think that this will give you system time and not ROS time so this will behave differently based on the real time factor. So I suggest going back to using now() or use rospy.get_rostime()

>>> print rospy.get_time()

content.raw:
+1

Though I still think it should be set to False at the beginning of the function and not the end, otherwise any piece of code changing this variable after init and before this function is called will cause this to use random data.

Quick note: this variable has no utility outside this function so it should be a local variable (in the function's scope), this would allow you to not allocate memory for it for the entire lifetime of the class' instance and prevent unexpected effect like the one I mentioned above
content.html:
+1

Though I still think it should be set to False at the beginning of the function and not the end, otherwise any piece of code changing this variable after init and before this function is called will cause this to use random data.

Quick note: this variable has no utility outside this function so it should be a local variable (in the function's scope), this would allow you to not allocate memory for it for the entire lifetime of the class' instance and prevent unexpected effect like the one I mentioned above
